episode_title: How to Become a Chick-fil-A Owner-Operator with Tim Sweetman
transcript:

All right, Tim Sweetman, Chick-fil-A franchisee. I am freaking excited to talk to you, because I know nothing about this space, and I go to Chick-fil-A every single week, like 50 % of America does. And I just want to learn about it. I want to figure out how this thing actually freaking works. Let me ask you a question. How many people did your Chick-fil-A location in Delaware service last year?


Tim Sweetman (00:42.337)
Actually, I did the math on this the other day. I'll phrase it this way. So I've been doing this for seven years. And we have served close to, I think it's about 3.5 million people since we opened in 2018. For us, we average around 40,000 customers every single month.


Nikolas Hulewsky (00:53.983)
Okay.

It certainly depends. And so, yeah, you can do the math on that, but we generally kind of look at that on regular basis.

40,000 customers a month. like almost 500,000 people or unique transactions, whatever the metric is, a year.

That's right. That's right. Yeah, an incredible opportunity for impact and influence for us. We get to see so many people. And of course, that represents transactions. It doesn't represent the fact that most of those transactions probably have more than one person that's tied to that transaction as well. And so you can multiply that across families and couples and other individuals that are coming into the restaurant.


Nikolas Hulewsky (01:51.241)
Sure.


Yeah, yeah, yeah.


A million, a million humans coming into your restaurant probably at least every year. So I did a little bit of research before we hopped on here. This was crazy to me. I wanted to know in the United States, cause I had heard the Chick-fil-A was good. Like what's the average annual spend per location? And so I went and looked at some comparative U S food chains and I have some numbers for you. you ready? Okay. You might, you might correct me. Here we go. average sales volume of a Whataburger.

Very possible.

Sure, let's do it.

$4 million a year. Average sales volume of a McDonald's. A little bit higher, but it's about $4 million a year. Average sales volume of a Chipotle. What do you think?


More or less. Yeah, yeah, yeah. 3.1. The next highest, here we go. Raising Canes, this was a high one. 5.7. Chick-fil-A. This blew my mind. $8 million. It gave me a range, but the middle of that range is $8 million. So Chick-fil-A on average per location does $8 million a year in revenue. On average, McDonald's does half of that, four.

Three? Four? Maybe?

They're killing it.

Chipotle does $3 million. Like, these are big businesses that you have 15 year olds who just tell you, my pleasure running. It's nuts to me. How does it work?

Yeah, I think even some of the most recent data from the FDD, I think Patrick Buckley had posted some of this, again, it's now north of 9 million if you include all of the different restaurants. obviously, there's a wide range that's there. Cheers.

And I heard an operator, he's been an operator for 40 plus years, say this, a couple weeks ago, is winning hearts starts with willing hearts. And so it really is all about people. What I've found, and we've done some of the research on this at Chick-fil-A, Chick-fil-A by and large invests more by a


huge magnitude in leadership and people compared to everyone else in QSR. And so it's this huge bet that we are investing in selecting talent. What does that mean? Like, what are they investing in?

is gonna sit down with a 15 year old or a 16 year old, unlikely to be 15, but a teenager and look at them and say, you fog and mirror, you're generally okay, let's go one interview, one and done and hire them on the spot. that, the pulse test. Yeah, boom, go. And that's a significant amount of industries. Chick-fil-A for the longest time and probably from the beginning has made the strategic bet


Nikolas Hulewsky (05:07.423)
I call it the pulse test. It's the pulse test. Do you have a pulse? Okay, cool, you're hired.


Tim Sweetman (05:20.863)
that we would rather run short of people than hire the wrong person. Culture is superior and we understand that ultimately the types of employees that we hire are going to be what ultimately the guest experiences and then causes them to return back to the restaurant at any given time. And so it is not uncommon for there to be two to three interviews for every single employee, whether they are 16 or 60.


Nikolas Hulewsky (05:22.559)
You

And in most cases, I would say, including my restaurant, I do every single final interview. I will not let a person be hired at my restaurant unless I personally have met them and spoken with them and make that decision. that person that's going to be in that front counter is representing you well. And so that's just uncommon. And I don't know that people, when I say invest, like that's a big investment, right? That's an investment of time and energy. You're probably having a person that's making 60, 70, $80,000 a year. That sole job at a chicken restaurant is to hire people, take them through orientation, train them, develop them, et cetera. And then on top of that,


We've made strategic bets for a long time that even before we had the volumes that we had, we were hiring high caliber people, paying them a lot of money, sacrificing in the short term, maybe some profitability in order to have world class leaders that were there that are also developing and growing the young people that we're hiring.


Nikolas Hulewsky (07:02.707)
Mm-hmm.


Let me ask you this question. If somebody on your team does not say, pleasure, when I say thank you, do they get fired?

They don't get fired, but they do get written down in the book.


Tim Sweetman (07:40.687)

Nikolas Hulewsky (07:48.211)
Yeah.

Hey, hey, hey, hey, hey, hey, hey, hey, hey, hey, hey, hey, hey, hey, hey,

Yeah, that's right. Not acceptable. Not acceptable. So yeah, we're

So is that one thing, like, I mean, I just never heard it explicitly said. Hey, we don't say you're welcome here, we say my pleasure. Like, is that outlined?


Tim Sweetman (08:14.803)
that is outlined in the past. wasn't, it was a cultural thing. And actually it's never, it hasn't been always part of who we are. Truett experienced it at the Ritz Carlton. I think he was actually having a conversation with Horace Schultze at the time. And Horace was talking about how Chick-fil-A needed to have a similar phrase, like my pleasure to upgrade the experience at Chick-fil-A. And Truett at the time just said,


I think I like my pleasure. That sounds great. And Horst was like, no, you can't do that. There's no way. You the Ritz Carlton is the Ritz Carlton, you know, ladies and gentlemen, serving ladies and gentlemen, there's no way that's going to work in a fast food restaurant. And Truett was adamant. And for years, it wasn't anything more than just an expectation. He would come back every single year as they gathered operators together and say, I want you to be saying my pleasure. I want you to be saying my pleasure. And that started in early 2000s.


it kind of grew and then there was an expectation for a long time and now it is a standard in the same way that we upgrade our language in a number of other ways. We try not to use the word customers, we use the word guests. You should never hear a team member come to your table and say, can I take the trash off the table? They're gonna say, can I just clear the table for you or clear the tray for you? We try to avoid, yeah, we try to say avoid the word trash.


Nikolas Hulewsky (09:36.073)
Really?


Tim Sweetman (09:39.712)
if at all possible, just to upgrade that language that's there. You're never gonna hear, in theory, a team member at the front counter say, can I help the next person? They will say, can I serve the next guest? We don't want to say anything like.


Nikolas Hulewsky (09:53.311)
Wow. It's funny, while you're saying that, I'm thinking back at my own experiences and be like, yeah, I get that. Yeah, that's true. That rings true.


Tim Sweetman (09:59.912)
That's right. We never use numbers. We're always gonna use names. We're gonna be asking for those names. And so I think that's one of the things that people don't realize about Chick-fil-A is obviously the very explicit open my pleasure thing happens, but it's the little details that sometimes guests don't notice and it's hard for them to put into words. Why is Chick-fil-A so different? And it's all the little things that add up. It's all those pieces of language. It's fresh flowers in the dining


Nikolas Hulewsky (10:25.343)
Mm-hmm.


Tim Sweetman (10:28.401)
You know, it's mints at the end of your meal. It's mouthwash in the bathrooms. It's the way that team members are dressed effectively. We absolutely have mouthwash. We have mouthwash in the bathrooms for guests. That's it.


Nikolas Hulewsky (10:36.063)
Wait, wait, wait, wait, your Chick-fil-A has mouthwash?


for guests?


I need, you need to call someone about the Meridian Chick-fil-A, because I need mouth washing my freaking Chick-fil-A, dude.


Tim Sweetman (10:48.924)
You imagine, isn't that great? I'm going, you know, it should be, you shouldn't be paying Ritz Carlton money for it, but you should be experiencing Ritz Carlton level service when you go to your local Chick-fil-A. That should be the expectation.


Nikolas Hulewsky (11:06.941)
Why do you think that shared language is important? Why do you think that, Hey, my pleasure. Why do you think guests instead of customer? Why tray instead of trash person, you know, like, why do you think that that's been such a focus of Chick-fil-A?


Tim Sweetman (11:22.151)
I think when the book Unreasonable Hospitality came out and also in the past, Danny Meyer's Setting the Table book came out. Those gave some language to that. And one of the things in Unreasonable Hospitality that the author talks about is how elevated hospitality, elevated language actually elevates the person.


You have selected people that have a heart of hospitality, they have a desire or willingness to do the thing that we're asking them. And then what they find is it's kind of that, you're more blessed to give than receive thing. And so when they use that upgraded language, when they don't say, I wanna help that person, when they say, wanna serve that guest, there's something powerful in the words that you use that actually change who you are and how you think.


Nikolas Hulewsky (11:47.647)
Hmm.


Tim Sweetman (12:15.182)
and will elevate you and your soul as a human being. And so it's this incredible flywheel effect that when, what you say, what you do, the kind of environment you create affects the whole person. And yeah, you just create this incredible environment, incredible flywheel that leads to success.


Nikolas Hulewsky (12:33.247)
Well, I say this a lot and sometimes people laugh at it and sometimes people roll their eyes, but cults are powerful. And many times, cults are built around shared language. And so if you think about, I'm LDS, grew up Mormon, right? I'm still Mormon to this day. Many people are Southern Baptists or whatever other religion you want to talk. Or you went to the University of Southern California undergrad, or maybe you went to Notre Dame or whatever. Shared language is really powerful.


And so when you create a shared language, you also create a shared identity and it brings people closer together. So when you've got, you know, this company culture where it's like, no, it's my pleasure. You guys are, are bonding each other. And so I've always felt like it's really important at the outset to define here's what our core values are. Here's what's most important to us here. It's the way that we will refer to certain things because it immediately creates a sense of buy-in and a sense of belonging. And it is it's cult-like, right? Like, I don't mean that in the negative sense, but


It is because you're creating now a shared experience among people that is greater than the sum of their parts.


Tim Sweetman (13:39.14)
And I think what also happens is it's repelling as well. So it's both a talent magnet, you're pulling in like-minded individuals that sense and want that belonging, but it's also a magnet can be repelling as well to the types of individuals and types of people that don't fit and don't belong in that culture. It's not for everybody. And that's okay. If it was for everybody, I don't think that people would want to come.


Nikolas Hulewsky (13:43.187)
Yep.


Nikolas Hulewsky (14:02.665)
Sure.


Tim Sweetman (14:08.59)
eat with us. We're not actually trying to be all things to all people necessarily when it comes to talent. They don't want to say my pleasure. They're not outgoing and engaging and that's just not for them and that's okay. That doesn't make them less of a person. It just makes them not a Chick-fil-A employee.


Nikolas Hulewsky (14:32.287)
Well, it's also a really good, it's a really good filter too. Like you hired somebody and they're like, they're not saying my pleasure. Where did this one come from? didn't.


Tim Sweetman (14:40.385)
Absolutely. Absolutely.


Tim Sweetman (14:51.563)
Yeah.

Right, right. It varies widely, would be the best way to answer that. So I'll answer it specific maybe to myself, or maybe paint a generic picture. So that can be a little confusing for some.


people and if there's phenomenal performance and a couple other things are met there may be additional ones. So you have the owner-operator. I think that owner-operator in the past was more the general manager. Now they serve as a combination of founder, CEO in that world. I think most Chick-fil-A's have some level of a general manager. We prefer to call them like a director of operations or an executive director.


that's gonna be a person with extensive experience. are really handling the day to day. In my particular business, for example, we run on the entrepreneurial operating system. Not every Chick-fil-A does that, but a lot of them have a similar system to that. And so in that world, you probably have the operator in the visionary seat and you have some person that's in the integrator seat. Interesting.

which is everything that you probably see on a regular basis, those cashiers and registers and iPads outside, and everything in the back of the house or Chick-fil-A. Mm.

that is overseeing those areas. There's now, I think there's usually somebody who's dedicated to marketing and events that's at a Chick-fil-A restaurant. Yeah.


Tim Sweetman (17:23.716)
And so we, again, intentional in language, a talent director who is in charge of doing the sourcing and interviewing and onboarding. So again, it's like operations, talent, marketing, training and development. I would say there's lots of different mixtures of those. Some stores have.


people that are solely dedicated to food safety and food quality. Some stores have additional director level.

employees so eight million dollars on average let's say how many employees is that at an average tick-fil-a

love.

as employees and then you tend to at night have much more part time. So I'm gonna guess it's somewhere in the 50-50 between full time and part time, maybe 40-60 depending on what's happening. Okay.

that are incredibly impressive when you look at their resumes. run business, really impressive. And then on the other side, we create an environment though, where you can have a high school educated individual or person that has moved up through the ranks and has just learned by doing. And that's the beauty of it. That's the incredible.


place that we've created where any type of person can thrive and survive. But yeah, I think in terms of comp, it's so hard to answer that because state to state, it's so different. if you are extremely, I think people are surprised is what I would say, at how much a person can make. Yeah.

Yes.

few places allow you to do that. And you get to do it across a wide spectrum of people.


Nikolas Hulewsky (23:35.081)
Okay, so you said earlier that you guys run on EOS and not everybody runs on EOS. You've said a couple of nuggets here where I'm like, it's not a one size fits all uniformed approach. Yeah, it's a franchise. It's just a very unique model. And there's people that are way smarter than me that understand the legalities of how in the heck this works. Okay.

Yeah.


Tim Sweetman (25:05.332)
potentially like an independent contractor or something like that. no, you don't own the real estate and there's nothing to sell on the other side of it. Okay.

Nikolas Hulewsky (25:49.727)

Tim Sweetman (26:11.4)
Yeah, I'd encourage people to go to Chick-fil-A's website on this to get the specifics. the requirements, as far as I know, there's no net worth requirements that are there. What that specifically looks like, I don't know if that's listed anywhere, but it

Sure.

That's it?


Do they just want to see you have some some skin in the game? Is that why? Like that just seems like an exceptionally low number.


Tim Sweetman (27:15.397)
have this huge financial nest egg. They may not be millionaires. And so they may have been running Chick-fil-A's for a long period of time. And so there's an opportunity for people that, and that's not a requirement, you know, to have worked at Chick-fil-A or done anything there, but I think there's a number of people that because of that low bar, they have what it takes in order to be an incredible owner operator of the business. You know, but on the back end,


and again it's all in the FDD, I encourage people to go find that, is the way it works is the franchise fee off of revenue ends up being 15 % and then after expenses and all of that, the profit, what we call net profit that you might see on a P &L is split particularly 50-50.
